user.biography: One of NASA's Great Observatories, helping us understand the structure & evolution of the Universe. For our Privacy Policy: http://www.si.edu/Privacy

node.text:
🔭🖼️ Are you up for a challenge? Participate in #NASA's Summer #AstrophotoChallenges! Use real telescope data to process your own images of this season's target, galaxy M87. 

👀 Watch the video to learn more and then get started by following the link at: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

#astronomy #space #astro #photo #project #enter

node.accessibility_caption: This image of Markarian 573 shows two cones of emission streaming away from the supermassive black hole at its center. The composite image shows overlap between X-rays from Chandra (blue), radio emission from the VLA (purple), and optical data from Hubble (gold).
This image is a wide-field view of the Puppis A supernova remnant.

node.text:
Puppis A was created when a star ended its life in a supernova explosion thousands of years ago, forming a neutron star & releasing debris into space. The explosion sent the star flying — it's still moving at over 4.8 million kilometers per hour, having traveled about 20 light years so far.😮

📱Want this #beautiful #pic as a #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🤔Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra & ROSAT): #NASA, CXC, GSFC, Middlebury College/F.Winkler et al., S.Snowden et al.;
Optical (Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory): #NOAO, AURA, NSF, Middlebury College/F.Winkler et al.

#stars #astrophysics #powerful #fast

node.accessibility_caption: This image is a wide-field view of the Puppis A supernova remnant.
This image is a wide-field view of the Puppis A supernova remnant along with an arrow and label pointing to the neutron star: RX J0822-4300.

This is an image of galaxy NGC 6118. It is a disk-shaped galaxy with several rather loosely wound spiral arms that spiral out directly from the nucleus. These arms show large numbers of active star-forming regions.

node.text:
🐍Today Chandra is gazing at a group of galaxies in Serpens, "the Serpent." Nearby in the sky is NGC 6118, a grand design spiral galaxy located about 83 million light years from Earth. This galaxy hosted a #supernova explosion seen in 2004 that has since faded with time. 

🔭Optical (32-inch Schulman Telescope): Adam Block/Mount Lemmon SkyCenter/University of Arizona

🖼️Want #beautiful #space #pics as #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

#cosmic #galaxy #astronomy #science

node.accessibility_caption:
This post contains an unlabeled version and a labeled version of the same graphic.

An artist's illustration in the main part of this graphic shows how the paths of light from distant objects are bent and amplified by a galaxy along the line of sight between Earth and the objects. The X-ray light from one of the objects on the left (purple) has been warped by the gravity of the intervening galaxy to produce two beams and X-ray sources ("A" and "B" in a labeled version) detected in the Chandra image, which is represented by the dashed square on the right. The X-ray light from the fainter object (blue) produces an X-ray source ("C") that has been amplified by the galaxy to be as much as 300 times brighter than it would have been without the lensing. The Chandra image is shown in the inset.

node.text:
🔍⚫By using a natural lens in space as an "X-ray magnifying glass," astronomers have captured an unprecedented look at X-rays from a #BlackHole system in the early Universe. The X-rays detected by Chandra were emitted by this system when the Universe was only 2 billion years old compared to its current age of nearly 14 billion years. More about the discovery in the comments...

➡️ Visit us to learn more about the #space #science behind the #images: https://chandra.harvard.edu/

Illustration: NASA, CXC, M. Weiss;
X-ray (Chandra, inset): #NASA, CXC, SAO/D. Schwartz et al.

#early #old #universe #galaxy #astronomy

An image of supernova remnant G292.0+1.8 in X-ray light. The image is somewhat spherical and contains different colors (chemical elements) woven throughout the object.

node.text:
🌟💥 This X-ray image of #supernova remnant G292.0+1.8 shows a rapidly expanding, intricate debris field that contains large amounts of oxygen (yellow & orange) and other elements such as magnesium (green) and silicon & sulfur (blue) that were forged in the #star before it exploded.

📱Want this #incredible #pic as #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, Chandra X-ray Center (CXC), Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO)

#space #chemistry #beautiful #universe

node.text:
🐶 Spiral galaxies IC 2163 & NGC 2207 are merging about 130 million light years from Earth in Canis Major, the Greater #Dog. Wonder if they sniffed each other first? Happy #NationalDogDay!

More:
IC 2163 and NGC 2207 are a pair of colliding spiral galaxies. Their bright central nuclei resemble a striking set of eyes. In visible light (Hubble), trails of stars and gas trace out spiral arms, stretched by the tidal pull between the galaxies. When seen in infrared light (IR; Spitzer), the glow of warm dust appears. This dust is the raw material for the creation of new stars and planets. Complementary to the IR, the X-ray (Chandra) view reveals areas of active star formation and the birth of super star clusters. Though individual stars are too far apart to collide, the material between the stars merges to create high-density pockets of gas. These regions gravitationally collapse to trigger a firestorm of starbirth. The galaxy collision will go on for several millions of years, leaving the galaxies completely altered in terms of their shapes.

📱Want this #beautiful #pic as a #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🤔Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra X-ray Observatory): NASA, CXC, SAO/S.Mineo et al.
Optical (Hubble Space Telescope): NASA, STScI
Infrared (Spitzer Space Telescope): NASA/JPL-Caltech

node.accessibility_caption: This multiwavelength image of galaxy 4C+29.30 contains X-ray data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory (blue), optical light obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope (gold) and radio waves from the NSF's Very Large Array (pink).

node.text:
⚫The intense #gravity of a supermassive black hole can be tapped to produce immense power in the form of jets of particles moving at millions of miles per hour. This image shows it happening in 4C+29.30, a galaxy located about 850 million light years away. 

📱Want this #beautiful #pic as a #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🔍Learn about the #space #science behind the #image: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, SAO, A.Siemiginowska et al;
Optical (#Hubble): NASA, STScI;
Radio (Very Large Array): NSF, NRAO, #VLA

#galaxy #cosmos #astronomy #fast #powerful #physics

node.accessibility_caption: Pluto nearly fills the frame in this image from the Long Range Reconnaissance Imager (LORRI) aboard NASA's New Horizons spacecraft, taken on July 13, 2015 when the spacecraft was 476,000 miles (768,000 kilometers) from the surface. This view is dominated by the large, bright feature informally named the "heart," which measures approximately 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) across. The heart borders darker equatorial terrains, and the mottled terrain to its east (right) are complex. However, even at this resolution, much of the heart's interior appears remarkably featureless.

node.text:
Can you believe it's been 15 years since #Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet?! #PlutoDemotedDay

In 2006, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) redefined what a planet is in our Solar System:
A planet is a celestial body that
✔️ a) is in orbit around the Sun,
✔️ b) has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and
❌ c) has cleared the neighborhood around its orbit.

Credit: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft (#NASA, APL, SwRI)

🖼️About the Image:
Pluto nearly fills the frame in this image from the Long Range Reconnaissance Imager (LORRI) aboard NASA's New Horizons spacecraft, taken on July 13, 2015 when the spacecraft was 476,000 miles (768,000 kilometers) from the surface. This view is dominated by the large, bright feature informally named the "heart," which measures approximately 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) across. The heart borders darker equatorial terrains, and the mottled terrain to its east (right) are complex. However, even at this resolution, much of the heart's interior appears remarkably featureless. 

#planets #space #SolarSystem #education #learn #science

node.accessibility_caption: An X-ray and optical image of a group of galaxies called NGC 5813 showing distinct cavities in the hot gas (shown in purple) surrounding a central, supermassive black hole which is too small to be identified in this image.

node.text:
⚫Cavities detected in multi-million degree gas show the supermassive #BlackHole at the center of NGC 5813 has erupted multiple times over 50 million years. Jets produced just outside of the black hole generate shock waves that push the gas outward and create huge holes — like an air bubble rising to the surface in water.

📱Free #wallpaper #pics for your phone or tablet: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🔍Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, SAO/S.Randall et al.
Optical (SDSS): Sloan Digital Sky Survey

#physics #astrophysics #powerful #hot #galaxies

node.accessibility_caption: An X-ray and optical image of a group of galaxies called NGC 5813 showing distinct cavities in the hot gas (shown in purple) surrounding a central, supermassive black hole which is too small to be identified in this image.
This image is the same as the first image in this post with the addition of yellow labels identifying six cavities.
A radio image of the Pinwheel Galaxy, M33. The rainbow of colors shown in this image is due to the rotation of the galaxy, which Doppler-shifts the radio light.

node.text:
🌈Objects in space produce a vast range of light with wavelengths too short or too long for our eyes to see. Radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible, UV, X-ray & gamma radiation are all different wavelengths of light. Check out this fantastic #radio pic from @national.radio.astronomy on #NationalRadioDay!

Image: M33
Credit: NRAO/AUI/NSF

🔍Learn more about this image and the invisible colors of radio light at: https://bit.ly/3z4OPvt

📱Get #beautiful #space #wallpaper for your phone or tablet: https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

#amazing #rainbow #colors #astronomy #wow

node.accessibility_caption: Image of N49 in X-ray and optical light. The bullet-shaped object (labeled in yellow) seen in X-rays in the lower right of the image is traveling away from a bright point source in the upper left part of N49.

node.text:
⭐💥 N49 is a supernova remnant located about 160,000 light years from Earth in the Large Magellanic Cloud. X-ray data reveal the presence of a bullet-shaped object being blown out of the debris field at about 8 million kilometers per hour — evidence that the supernova explosion was highly asymmetric. This image is roughly 75 light years across.

🖼️Want this #beautiful #pic as a #background #wallpaper for your phone or tablet? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/wallpaper/

🤔Want to know more about the #space #science behind the #image? https://chandra.harvard.edu/instagram/

X-ray (Chandra): #NASA, CXC, Penn State/S.Park et al.; 
Optical (#Hubble): NASA, STScI, UIUC/Y.H.Chu & R.Williams et al.

#Universe #fast #astronomy #hot #astrophysics #powerful #physics

node.accessibility_caption: Image of N49 in X-ray and optical light. The bullet-shaped object (labeled in yellow) seen in X-rays in the lower right of the image is traveling away from a bright point source in the upper left part of N49.
Image of N49 in X-ray and optical light. The bullet-shaped object seen in X-rays in the lower right of the image is traveling away from a bright point source in the upper left part of N49.
Puppis A is seen as a red dusty cloud that resembles the shape of a rose in this image from NASA's Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, or WISE. Puppis A is the remnant of a supernova explosion.

node.text:
📜 "Traveling Light Hertz with Frequency"

A rose seen in infrared, 
Ultraviolet Sun seen in blue,
It's #BadPoetryDay today and we want to read yours also.

Puppis A (Infrared): #NASA's Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE)
The Sun (Ultraviolet): NASA's Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO)

#space #poetry #astronomy #roses #violets

node.accessibility_caption: Puppis A is seen as a red dusty cloud that resembles the shape of a rose in this image from NASA's Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, or WISE. Puppis A is the remnant of a supernova explosion.
This image of the Sun in shades of blue was taken in ultraviolet light by the Extreme-ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (EIT) on board the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) spacecraft.
